relations.head: fat mass and obesity-associated protein
relations.label: reduce
relations.text: The Von Hippel-Lindau-deficient cells expressing FTO restores mitochondrial activity, induces oxidative stress and ROS production and shows impaired tumour growth, through increasing expression of PGC-1alpha by reducing m6A levels in its mRNA transcripts.

relations.head: N6-methyladenosine
relations.label: is on
relations.text: The Von Hippel-Lindau-deficient cells expressing FTO restores mitochondrial activity, induces oxidative stress and ROS production and shows impaired tumour growth, through increasing expression of PGC-1alpha by reducing m6A levels in its mRNA transcripts.

relations.head: PGC-1alpha
relations.label: reduce
relations.text: The Von Hippel-Lindau-deficient cells expressing FTO restores mitochondrial activity, induces oxidative stress and ROS production and shows impaired tumour growth, through increasing expression of PGC-1alpha by reducing m6A levels in its mRNA transcripts.

relations.head: tumour growth
relations.label: reduce
relations.text: The low expression of FTO in human ccRCC correlates with increased tumour severity and poor patient survival.

relations.head: fat mass and obesity-associated protein
relations.label: increase
relations.text: The low expression of FTO in human ccRCC correlates with increased tumour severity and poor patient survival.

analysis:
Context:  
Because the molecular mechanism is explicitly linked to clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC), the context is “clear cell renal cell carcinoma,” and the context type is “disease.”

Nodes:  
1) fat mass and obesity-associated protein (FTO): gene, downregulated in ccRCC  
2) N6-methyladenosine (m6A): RNA modification, NULL  
3) PGC-1alpha: protein, NULL  
4) tumour growth: clinical phenotype, NULL  
5) patient survival: clinical phenotype, NULL  

Regulatory Relationships (Summarized):  
• FTO reduces m6A, which leads to increased PGC-1alpha expression (meta-relation).  
• m6A is on PGC-1alpha.  
• PGC-1alpha reduces tumour growth.  
• tumour growth reduces patient survival.  
• FTO increases patient survival (inferred from low FTO correlating with poor survival).
